caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 51.
Caecum teres
. A . Profile view with periostracum (LACM 1967-15.18). B . Profile view without periostracum (LACM 1967-15.18). C . Ventral view (LACM 1967-70.30). D . Operculum, exterior surface (LACM 1967-15.18). E . Operculum, interior surface (LACM 1967-15.18). F . Syntype, NHMUK 1857.6.4.1550. G . Close-up of periostracum (LACM 1967- 15.18). H . Profile view with periostracum (LACM 1967-15.18). I . Profile view without periostracum (LACM 1967-70.30). J . Close-up of surface without periostracum (LACM 1967-70.30).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 52.
Caecum teres
shells at different growth stages. A . Teleoconchs II to IV (LACM 1967-70.30). B . Surface of teleoconchs II to V (LACM 1967-70.30). C . Surface of teleoconchs III to V (LACM 1967-70.30). D . Teleoconchs IV to V (LACM 1973-5.50). E . Teleoconch V (LACM 1973-5.50).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and Habitat. From Magdalena Bay, Baja California , Mexico to Sechura Bay, Peru , including the Gulf of California, the Revillagigedo Islands, Cocos Island, and the Galapagos Islands. Intertidal to
55 m .
Common on sand and rubble substrates.

Remarks. The largest specimen from the type material of
Caecum teres
is a late subadult (NHMUK 1857.6.4.1550, Fig. 51F ). The surface of
C. teres
may appear smooth or display microsculpture consisting of short, longitudinal striae ( Figs. 51 I–J). However, the periostracum always has well-defined microsculpture ( Figs. 51 G–H). Adult
C. teres
and
C. corrugulatum
have similar shaped teleoconchs. However, their growth morphologies and microsculpture are quite different.
